title: Example: Monorepo Build Orchestration
description: Create working example showing parallel package builds with caching for monorepo scenario
close_reason:
âœ… Fixed critical dependency execution bug and completed working monorepo example

CRITICAL FIX IMPLEMENTED:
- gaffer-exec was NOT executing dependencies declared in 'deps' field for atomic graphs  
- Added expand_atomic_graph_with_deps() to detect and expand atomic graphs with deps into composites
- Dependencies now execute in correct topological order before main commands
- Tested: rm -rf packages/*/dist && gaffer-exec run start â†’ all packages build, app runs successfully

ISSUES RESOLVED:
1. âœ… Dependencies execute transitively (clean â†’ shared-lib â†’ services â†’ gateway â†’ web-app â†’ build-all â†’ start)
2. âœ… Build artifacts (dist folders) created before use  
3. âœ… Test assertions fixed (packages vs services, web-app vs shared-lib)
4. âœ… Example works end-to-end as documented

COMMITS:
- gaffer: 8d37b9e fix(gaffer-exec): execute dependencies for atomic graphs with deps
- gaffer-public: 32bb8bf fix(examples): correct test assertions, merged to main

All tests pass. Example demonstrates real-world TypeScript monorepo builds with parallel execution.

title: Create verifiable examples for all gaffer-exec use cases
description:
Create WORKING, EXECUTABLE examples for all gaffer-exec use cases documented in docs/gaffer-exec-use-cases.md.

**CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS:**
1. Each example MUST use a known, popular open source project (not toy/mock code)
2. Each example MUST have a graph.json file that can be executed with gaffer-exec
3. Each example MUST have actual executable scripts/code (not just documentation)
4. Users MUST be able to run 'gaffer-exec run <task>' and see it work
5. Include README explaining what the example demonstrates and how to run it
6. Examples MUST be placed in hedinfaok/gaffer-public repository under examples/ directory

**Definition of Done per example:**
- Uses real open source project (document how to clone/setup)
- graph.json exists and validates
- Tasks defined in graph.json can be executed successfully
- At least one runnable command demonstrated (e.g., gaffer-exec run build)
- README documents what command to run and expected output
- Example demonstrates core value proposition of use case
- Setup instructions include any git clone/version requirements

**NOT acceptable:**
- Toy/mock examples
- Documentation-only exa- Documentation-only exa-not be executed
- Examples without graph.json files

title: Example: Multi-Format Documentation Generation
description:
USER STORY: As a technical writer, I want orchestrated documentation generation that produces multiple output formats from a single source with cross-references and dependency tracking, so that I can maintain comprehensive documentation across different delivery channels.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ“š Cross-Format Dependency Tracking: Automatically regenerates affected docs when source code, APIs, or referenced content changes vs manual rebuilds

âš¡ Intelligent Asset Processing: Dynamic diagram generation, screenshot updates, and code example extraction from live codebase vs static assets

ğŸ§  Multi-Source Content Orchestration: Combines README files, code comments, API specs, and manual content into unified documentation vs single-source tools

ğŸ“Š Content Validation Pipeline: Checks broken links, validates code examples, ensures cross-references work across all output formats vs post-hoc validation

ğŸ” Smart Build Optimization: Only regenerates changed sections and dependent content vs full site rebuilds

ğŸ’¡ Format-Aware Optimization: Optimizes content for each output format (interactive HTML, print PDF, mobile-friendly) from single source vs one-size-fits-all

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
â€¢ Multi-format output (HTML, PDF, Markdown, DocX, EPUB)
â€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deï¿½ï¿½shoâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentatioe, â€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documer-â€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documenupdâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documentation deâ€¢ Documtures), Docusaurus (React-only) with intelligent multi-format orchestration.

title: Example: Network-Aware Builds
description:
USER STORY: As a distributed systems developer, I want network-aware build workflows that optimize for bandwidth, handle network failures gracefully, and efficiently distribute build artifacts, so that I can maintain fast and reliable builds across geographically distributed teams and infrastructure.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸŒ Intelligent Network Topology Awareness: Auto-discovers network conditions and adapts task distribution vs static remote build configurations

âš¡ Adaptive Bandwidth Optimization: Dynamic compression and delta transfers based on network conditions vs fixed transfer protocols

ğŸ§  Network Failure Resilience: Exponential backoff with intelligent mirror fallbacks and partial transfer resumption vs simple retry logic

ğŸ“Š Multi-Region Caching Strategy: Geo-distributed cache synchronization with conflict resolution vs single cache servers

title: Example: Asset Processing
description:
USER STORY: As a frontend developer, I want orchestrated asset processing workflows that optimize images, compile stylesheets, and bundle JavaScript with intelligent dependency-aware caching, so that I can build optimized web applications faster than traditional build tools.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ¯ Cross-Format Dependency Resolution: Automatic tracking of dependencies across asset types (SCSS to images, JS to CSS, fonts to CSS) vs manual configuration in Webpack/Vite

âš¡ Resource-Aware Parallel Processing: Intelligent parallel asset processing that adapts to CPU/memory constraints vs naive parallel processing

ğŸ§  Advanced Caching Strategy: Content-based cache invalidation across asset types - CSS recompiles when referenced images change vs timestamp-based caching

ğŸ“Š Dynamic Optimization Pipelines: Environment-aware asset optimization - development gets unminified assets, production gets optimized bundles vs static pipeline configs

title: Example: Multi-Stage Deployments
description:
**USER STORY:**
As a deployment engineer, I want orchestrated multi-stage deployments that promote applications through dev/staging/production with validation gates and automated rollback capabilities.

**ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:**
- Multi-environment pipeline (dev â†’ staging â†’ production)
- Automated validation at each stage (tests, health checks)
- Rollback capability on failures
- Environment-specific configurations
- Real containerized application example
- Integration with CI/CD tools
- Create examples/09-multi-stage-deployments/

title: Example: Buildroot/Embedded Systems
description:
**USER STORY:**
As an embedded systems developer, I want orchestrated buildroot and cross-compilation workflows with dependency management for embedded targets, so that I can efficiently build complex embedded systems with proper toolchain management and target-specific optimizations.

**ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:**
- Cross-compilation for multiple embedded targets (ARM, RISC-V, etc.)
- Buildroot configuration and dependency management  
- Toolchain management and version consistency
- Target-specific build configurations and optimizations
- Real embedded project example (IoT device, router, etc.)
- Integration with hardware testing and deployment
- Create examples/17-embedded-systems/

title: Example: ETL Pipeline Execution
description:
USER STORY: As a data engineer orchestrating ETL pipelines, I want intelligent data processing workflows with automatic resource scaling and failure recovery, so that I can process large datasets efficiently with minimal infrastructure waste.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ”„ **Auto-Resource Scaling:** Memory/CPU allocation adapts to dataset size - small CSVs use minimal resources while large Parquet files get full system allocation

âš¡ **Smart Pipeline Parallelism:** Processes independent data partitions simultaneously while respecting memory constraints and I/O bottlenecks

ğŸ§  **Intelligent Retry Logic:** Exponential backoff with checkpointing - resumes failed ETL jobs from last successful stage rather than restarting entirely

ğŸ“Š **Performance Benchmarks:** Compare gaffer-exec vs Apache Airflow vs Prefect for pipeline efficiency and resource utilization

Create examples/10-etl-pipelines/ with real-world data processing scenario showcasing automatic scaling and checkpoint recovery.

title: Example: Benchmark Suite Execution
description:
USER STORY: As a performance engineer, I want automated benchmark suite execution with intelligent resource management and performance regression detection, so that I can monitor application performance with more accurate and efficient benchmarks than traditional tools.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ¯ Resource-Aware Benchmarking: Automatic CPU/memory isolation and resource allocation per benchmark vs shared resource contention in CI/CD

âš¡ Intelligent Benchmark Scheduling: Dependency-aware execution (warm-up â†’ load â†’ stress tests) with automatic retry on statistical outliers

ğŸ§  Cross-Benchmark Dependency Tracking: Database benchmarks wait for setup completion, web benchmarks use established DB performance baselines vs manual coordination

ğŸ“Š Dynamic Environment Normalization: Automatic system resource detection and benchmark parameter adjustment for consistent results across machines

VS ALTERNATIVES: Beats Jenkins (resource contention), GitHub Actions (limited resources), custom scripts (no orchestration) with intelligent benchmark orchestration and statistical analysis.

title: Example: Compliance Scanning
description:
USER STORY: As a security engineer, I want orchestrated compliance scanning workflows that perform security audits, license checks, and vulnerability assessments with result caching and policy enforcement, so that I can ensure applications meet security and compliance requirements.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ¯ Multi-Tool Orchestration: Coordinates SAST, DAST, dependency scanners (OWASP, Snyk, SonarQube) in intelligent sequence vs running tools independently

âš¡ Smart Result Caching: Avoids redundant scans using content-based caching - only rescans changed code/dependencies vs time-based or no caching

ğŸ§  Risk-Based Prioritization: Automatically prioritizes vulnerabilities by exploitability, asset criticality, and exposure vs flat severity lists

ğŸ“Š Policy-as-Code Engine: Configurable compliance gates with automatic remediation suggestions vs manual policy enforcement

ğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across nerğŸ” Cross-Language Security An reğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlatioancğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability cintğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerabilitity scanğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unified vulnerability correlation across poğŸ” Cross-Language Security Analysis: Unis
â€¢ Cross-language security analysis with correlation
â€¢ Incremental scanning based on code/dependency changes

EXAMPLE STRUCTURE:
examples/15-compliance-scanning/

â”œâ”€â”€ tools/ (OWASP ZAP, Bandit, ESLint security configs)
â”œâ”€â”€ reports/ (vulnerability reports, compliance dashboards)

VS ALTERNATIVES: Beats GitHub Actions security scanning, Jenkins OWASP plugin, SonarCloud (single-tool approach) with intelligent multi-tool security orchestration.

title: Example: Cross-Platform Builds
description:
USER STORY: As a software developer targeting multiple platforms, I want orchestrated cross-platform build workflows that handle platform-specific dependencies and configurations, so that I can efficiently build and test applications across Windows, macOS, and Linux from a single workflow definition.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ¯ Platform-Aware Dependency Resolution: Automatically resolves platform-specific dependencies and toolchains (MSBuild, Xcode, GCC) vs manual platform configuration

âš¡ Intelligent Cross-Compilation Orchestration: Optimizes native vs cross-compilation decisions based on target platforms and performance requirements vs fixed strategies

ğŸ§  Smart Resource Allocation: Distributes builds across available platforms with automatic fallback to cross-compilation when native builders unavailable vs static allocation

ğŸ“Š Cross-Platform Test Orchestration: Coordinates platform-specific testing with result correlation and platform-specificğŸ“Š Cross-Platform Test Orchestration: Coordinates platform-specific testing with result correlation and platform-specificğŸ“Š Cross-Platform Test Orchestration: Coordinates platform-specific testing with result correlation and platform-specificğŸ“Š Cross-Platform Test Orchestration: Coordinates platform-specific testing with result correlationsğŸ“Š Cross-Platform Test Orchesld systems

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
â€¢ Multi-platform build orchestration (Windows, macOS, Linux) from single graph.json
â€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-srtiâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specific dependency management and autoâ€¢ Platform-specification (Electron app, Go CLI, Rust desktop app)
â€¢ Create examples/19-cross-platform-builds/ with multi-platform CI comparison
â€¢ Commands: gaffer-exec run build-all-platforms, test-cross-platform, package-installers

VS ALTERNATIVES: Beats GitHub Actions (limited runners), Azure DevOps (expensive), Jenkins (complex setup) with intelligent platform-aware orchestration.

title: Example: Database Migration Orchestration
description:
USER STORY: As a database administrator, I want orchestrated database migration workflows with intelligent dependency management and automated rollback capabilities, so that I can safely evolve schema across multiple databases and environments with automatic conflict detection.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ¯ Cross-Database Dependency Resolution: Automatic dependency tracking across multiple databases (primary, analytics, cache, read replicas) vs single-database tools

âš¡ Intelligent Rollback Orchestration: Graph-based rollback planning with partial failure recovery and cascade analysis vs simple version-based rollbacks

ğŸ§  Concurrent Migration Management: Safe parallel migrations across non-conflicting schema areas with automatic conflict detection vs sequential-only migrations

ğŸ“Š Dynamic Validation Pipelines: Environment-aware validation with different rules per environment (dev vs staging vs prod) vs static validation rules

ğŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” VisutrağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Vis cğŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration stğŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” VisunchğŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migration MağŸ” Visual Migraatabase-migrations/ with traditional tool comparisons
â€¢ Commands: gaffer-exec run migrate-all, rollback-safe, validate-schema, migration-graph

VS ALTERNATIVES: Beats Flyway (single DB), Liquibase (limited orchestration), Alembic (Python-only) with intelligent multi-database orchestration and rollback planning.

title: Example: Infrastructure Provisioning
description:
USER STORY: As a DevOps engineer, I want orchestrated infrastructure provisioning with dependency-aware deployments and intelligent resource management, so that I can provision complex multi-tier infrastructures with automatic dependency resolution and rollback capabilities.

GAFFER-EXEC ADVANTAGES vs Terraform/Ansible/CloudFormation:
â€¢ DYNAMIC DEPENDENCY RESOLUTION: Real-time dependency analysis vs static dependency declarations
â€¢ RESOURCE-AWARE PROVISIONING: Intelligent parallel provisioning with resource conflict detection
â€¢ AUTOMATIC ROLLBACK ORCHESTRATION: Graph-based rollback with partial failure recovery
â€¢ CROSS-PROVIDER INTEGRATION: Seamlessly integrate AWS, GCP, Azure resources in single workflow
â€¢ INTELLIGENT CACHING: Infrastructure state caching with change-based invalidation
â€¢ VISUAL DEPENDENCY MAPPING: Interactive graph visualization of infrastructure dependencies

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
â€¢ Multi-tier infrastructure: VPC â†’ Subnets â†’ Security Groups â†’ Load Balancers â†’ Instances â†’ Applications
â€¢ Cross-provider resources (AWS RDS + GCP Cloud Storage + local Docker containers)
â€¢ Dependency-aware provisioning order with parallel optimization
â€¢ Automatic rollback on failures with partial cleanup
â€¢ Infrastructure state visualization and monitorinâ€¢ Infrastructure state visualization and monitorinâ€¢ Inmiâ€¢ Infrastructure state visualization and monitorinâ€¢ Infrastructure state visualization and mo vs traditional IaC orchestration
â€¢ CREATE: examples/09-infrastructure-provisioning/

title: Example: Watch Mode Workflows
description:
USER STORY: As a developer working on complex applications, I want intelligent watch mode workflows that rebuild only what changed and restart dependent services automatically, so that I can have fast development feedback loops without manual intervention.

KEY GAFFER-EXEC DIFFERENTIATORS:

ğŸ” Smart File System Watching: Advanced pattern matching and ignore rules - tracks .js/.ts/.py/.css changes while ignoring node_modules, .git, temp files vs simple timestamp-based watching

âš¡ Incremental Rebuild Intelligence: Dependency-aware rebuilds - only rebuild what actually changed and its dependents vs full rebuilds on any change

ğŸ”„ Cascading Service Orchestration: Intelligent service restart cascades - shared library changes restart dependent services, API changes restart frontends with graceful shutdown vs manual process management

ğŸ§  Smart Debouncing: Configurable debouncing prevents restart storms from rapid file saves vs immediate restarts on every change

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
â€¢ Create examples/07-watch-workflows/ with multi-service watch demo
â€¢ Implement intelligent file watching with configurable ignore patterns
â€¢ Show dependency-aware incremental rebuilds (library -> service -> frontend)
â€¢ Demonstrate smart debouncing preventing restart stormsâ€¢ Demonstrate smart debouncinker Compose/nodemon (rebuild speed, resource usage)

title: Example: Polyglot Task Running
description:
USER STORY: As a developer working with polyglot codebases, I want unified task orchestration that replaces npm scripts, Makefiles, and shell scripts with intelligent cross-language dependency resolution.

GAFFER-EXEC ADVANTAGES:
â€¢ UNIFIED EXECUTION: Single graph.json vs scattered build files
â€¢ CROSS-LANGUAGE DEPS: Automatic dependency resolution across Node.js, Python, Go, Rust
â€¢ RESOURCE-AWARE PARALLEL: Intelligent parallel execution vs sequential Make
â€¢ ADVANCED CACHING: Cross-language cache invalidation vs language-specific caching
â€¢ AUTO-TOOL DETECTION: Automatic npm/pip/go/cargo detection vs manual management

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
â€¢ Node.js frontend + Python ML + Go API + Rust CLI real example
â€¢ Replace package.json scripts, Makefiles, setup.py with single graph.json
â€¢ Cross-language dependencies (Pythonâ†’Node.js, Goâ†’Python, etc.)
â€¢ Performance benchmarks vs traditional multi-tool approach
â€¢ Commands: build-all, test-all, dev, lint-all
â€¢ CREATE: examples/08-polyglot-task-running/

title: Migration from Legacy Tools - gaffer-exec Showcase
description: Demonstrate gaffer-exec's superior auto-port detection, intelligent caching, and resource-aware parallel execution vs legacy tools like Jenkins, Make, and Docker Compose. Show real migration from Jenkins pipeline to gaffer-exec with performance benchmarks and specific technical advantages. Create examples/16-legacy-migration/ with before/after comparisons highlighting gaffer-exec's unique capabilities.
